Graphical abstract A robust and efficient Ni@NC-T quasi-molecular catalyst with highly coordinated Ni-N5 site was prepared by post-metallization of a pre-synthesized N-doped carbon (NC-T) support. The optimum Ni@NC-1100 catalyst exhibited an extremely high FE toward CO formation (>99%) at −0.72 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). Of interest is the FECO maintained above 96% over a wide potential window from −0.52 V to −1.12 V, outperforming almost all prior pyrolyzed Ni-N-C-based catalysts. Electrochemical production of high value-added CO from CO2 on transition metal-nitrogen-carbon (M−N−C) catalysts is a promising approach to achieve carbon neutral economy, yet the quest for robust catalysts is driven by achieving > 96 % CO faradaic efficiency (FE) under low overpotential and wide potential range. Herein, we report a novel synthetic approach involving post-metallization of the pre-synthesized N-doped carbon (NC-T) support for the fabrication of robust and efficient Ni@NC-T quasi-molecular catalysts toward CO2 electroreduction reaction (CO2RR). The optimum Ni@NC-1100 catalyst exhibited an extremely high FECO > 99 % at −0.72 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). Of interest is the FECO maintained above 96 % over a wide potential window from −0.52 V to −1.12 V. Density functional theory (DFT) calculation validated that the presence of axial pyrrolic-N significantly enhances the Ni-N5 active site for CO2 activation, resulting in the lowest activation energy for the *COOH intermediate generation compared to other axial ligands. Keywords CO2 electroreduction Ni-N5 site N-doped carbon Post-metallization Density functional theory Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The electrochemically converting greenhouse CO2 into high value-added fuels and chemicals has received increasing attention because of its great significance for both environmental protection and energy crisis mitigation [1,2]. Nevertheless, the practical implementation of such technology is highly challenging owing to the inert nature of CO2 with an extremely high bond energy (806 kJ·mol−1) and the multielectron and multiproton transfer processes involved in transforming it into a variety of C1 and C2+ products [3–5]. Of all products, CO is considered to be the closest to commercialization. Thus far, a large number of catalytic materials have been prepared and evaluated for CO2 electroreduction reaction (CO2RR). Noble metals such as Au, Pd, and Ag etc. have shown excellent electrochemical CO2-to-CO conversion performance at relatively low overpotentials, however, their scarcity and high cost have hampered the large-scale applications [6–10]. Alternatively, the emerging non-noble metal single-atom catalysts (SACs) have exhibited great advantages as promising high-efficiency and low-cost systems by virtue of their high intrinsic activity and maximized atom utilization [11–13]. Nevertheless, constructing stable SACs with high activity and selectivity remains a challenging task due to the high surface energy of single atoms. Atomically dispersed non-noble metals on nitrogen-doped carbon (M−N−C) with MNx active sites are promising catalysts for CO2RR due to their special electronic and geometric structure [14–16]. The MNx site is normally surrounded by 2 ∼ 4 N atoms [17,18], whereas unique coordination structure, especially the higher five-coordinated structure (MN5) reveals a significant increase in the activity of CO2RR, oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), and lithium-sulfur batteries etc. [19–22]. The peculiar structure and coordination environment of MN5 moiety endow them with favourable kinetics and excellent catalytic activity when N coordination atoms are present in the axial direction [23–26]. Recently, high-performance heterogeneous catalysts encompassing MN5 moieties have been designed and prepared via topo-chemical transformation, multi-step pyrolysis of organometallic complexes, and metal phthalocyanine axial coordination approaches [27–29]. Despite these advances, the synthesis of SACs with a MN5 moiety is still in its infancy, and universal strategies for controlling the type and content of metal sites need to be developed [30–32]. Further, unravelling the coordination environment and electronic structure of MN5 moieties in SACs at the molecular level and understanding the structure–property relationship in CO2RR are particularly desirable but extremely challenging. Herein, we designed and constructed a new kind of Ni-N5 sites immobilized on a N-doped carbon matrix using NiCl2 as the metal source through a simple adsorption and pyrolysis-free strategy. By a combined aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy (AC-STEM), X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses, the local atomic structure of Ni sites was confirmed as an unusual quinquidentate Ni-N5 moiety, distinct from the conventional NiN4 configuration. Impressively, the prepared Ni@NC-1100 quasi-molecular catalyst exhibited remarkable performance for CO2RR in 0.5 M KHCO3 solution with a high CO faradaic efficiency (FE) over 96 % in a wide potential range (−0.52 V ∼ − 1.12 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode, RHE) as well as excellent long-term stability, surpassing most of the state-of-the-art catalysts reported in the literature. The Tafel slope of Ni@NC-1100 electrode was determined to be 150.2 mV dec−1 much lower than those of Co@NC-1100 (201.1 mV dec−1) and Fe@NC-1100 (225.8 mV dec−1), suggesting the favorable reaction kinetics for the first electron transfer of adsorbed CO2. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations proved that the NiN4 with axial pyrrolic-N in Ni@NC-1100 serves as the intrinsic active site for CO2RR to CO. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and reagents 2,6-diaminopyridine (DAP), Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, potassium bicarbonate and magnesium oxide (MgO) were provided by Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. NiCl2, FeCl2, CuCl2, CoCl2 and ZnCl2 were provided by Tokyo Chemical Industry Co., Ltd. N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) and ethanol were provided by Meryer Co., Ltd. All of other reagents were used directly and without any treatment. 2.2 Synthesis of NC support The NC support was synthesized by a magnesium oxide template combined with zinc-mediated synthetic strategy [33]. Typically, 8.0 g of MgO and 4.36 g of DAP were dispersed in 50 mL of H2O in ultrasonic bath for 0.5 h, then 4.76 g of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O dissolved in 50 mL of H2O was slowly added into the above suspension. The mixture was continually stirred at 60 °C for 6 h. After evaporation of water under vacuum, the resultant DAP/Zn/MgO solid composite was thermally treated at 900, 1000, and 1100 °C (ramp rate: 5 °C/min) for 2 h under a flowing argon atmosphere. The obtained black powder was etched in 50 mL of 1.0 mol/L HCl solution at 100 °C for 12 h to remove the MgO template and those unstable zinc species, and then thoroughly washed to a neutral condition with deionized water and dried at 60 °C. 2.3 Synthesis of Ni@NC-T catalyst Typically, 100 mg of NC support and 20 mL of N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) were added into a 100 mL of glass flask and ultrasonically dispersed for 15 min. Subsequently, 10 mL of DMF solution of anhydrous NiCl2 (2 mg/mL) was added into the dispersion of NC support. After being flushed five times with argon, the mixture was stirred at 150 °C for 24 h, centrifuged and washed with deionized water and ethanol several times, and finally dried overnight at 60 °C under vacuum. The obtained product was denoted as Ni@NC-T and used directly without any further treatment (NC represented the N-doped carbon, T referred to the carbonization temperature). The Ni content in Ni@NC-T catalyst was determined to be 2.81 ∼ 8.25 wt% based on ICP-MS analysis. For comparison, the identical procedure was applied to prepare Fe-, Co–, Cu- and Zn-based N-doped carbon catalyst except for adding 10 mL of DMF solution of anhydrous FeCl2 (2 mg/mL), CoCl2 (2 mg/mL), CuCl2 (2 mg/mL) or ZnCl2 (2 mg/mL) into the dispersion solution of NC. 2.4 Electrochemical measurements All electrochemical tests were carried out on a CHI 660E potentiostat at ambient temperature and pressure in a three-electrode system. A platinum sheet was used as the counter electrode, and saturated Ag/AgCl was applied as the reference electrode. A high-purity CO2 gas saturated 0.5 M of KHCO3 solution was used as both the catholyte and anolyte, and a flow rate of 20 mL/min CO2 was maintained through the cathodic electrolyte during the whole test. All the potentials are corrected to RHE according to E RHE = E°Ag/AgCl (0.20 V) + E Ag/AgCl + 0.059 × pH. Before the electrochemical test, CO2 was insufflated into the KHCO3 for 0.5 h with a flow rate of 40 mL/min to fill the electrolyzer with CO2, and 30 min of controlled electrostatic potential electrolysis was acquired at each corresponding potential. The gaseous product in the cell was collected by a gas bag and its composition was analyzed by an HXSP GC-950 gas chromatography system, which is equipped with two thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a flame ionization detector (FID) with helium as an internal standard. Under the same conditions (such as pressure, temperature, and time), 20 mL of gas product in the dead volume of a gas bag (∼2.0 L) was infused into the GC by sample lock syringe. The mole fractions of CO and H2 of the infused samples were tested from the GC calibration curve. After each electrolysis, the obtained liquid products were taken out and quantified by 1H (1H NMR, Bruker 400 MHz) with a suppression of the water peak. The average result of three trials was also reported in this work. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were carried out by applying an AC voltage with 5 mV amplitude in a frequency range from 100 kHz to 100 mHz. The stability of Ni@NC-1100 catalyst was studied by continuous electrolysis for 24 h and the gas phase components were tested by GC at one hour intervals. The FE of CO/H2 and partial current density were calculated as the formulas: F E CO = C CO × S × 2 F P / RT / I total F E H 2 = C H 2 × S × 2 F P / RT / I total J CO = C CO × S × 2 F P / RT / A J H 2 = C H 2 × S × 2 F P / RT / A where C CO, and C H2 refer to the concentration of CO and H2 measured by GC, S (flow rate of CO2) = 15 mL/min, F (Faraday constant) = 96485C·mol−1, P (atmospheric pressure) = 101.3 KPa, R (gas constant) = 8.314 J mol−1 K−1, T (thermodynamic temperature = 298.15 K, A refers to the geometric area of the electrode, I total refers to the measured current. The turnover frequency (TOF) of CO formation was calculated as following equations: T O F h - 1 = J CO × S / ZF / m cat . × w / M Ni × 3600 where J CO represents CO partial current (A cm−2), S refers to the geometric surface area of working electrode (cm2), F (Faraday constant) = 96485C mol−1, Z stands for the number of electrons transferred (Z = 2 for CO formation), m cat. refers to the mass of catalyst in the electrode (g), M Ni (atomic mass of Ni) = 58.69 g mol−1, w refers to loading of Ni in the catalyst. Tafel slope was achieved from the Tafel equation: E = a + b l o g ( j C O ) where E is the overpotential, a is a constant, b is the Tafel slope and j CO is the CO partial current density. 2.5 Characterization The Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were acquired by a Nicolet iS5 spectrophotometer (KBr pellet). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was measured using an FEI Tecnai G2 F20S-Twin with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The materials were dispersed in ethanol by ultrasonication, and a drop of the solution was placed on a micro grid. X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) spectroscopy were conducted with a 1W2B beamline of the Beijing synchrotron radiation facility. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out using PHI-5702 instrument and the C 1 s line at 284.5 eV was used as the binding energy reference. X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were recorded with Rigaku Ultima IV diffractometer using Cu-Kα radiation in the 2θ range of 5-90°. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms were used an ASAP2020 analyzer. Before measurement, all samples were degassed under vacuum at 393 K for 6 h. Surface area of the samples were calculated by the Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) method, and pore volume and size distribution were calculated with the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) model. Raman spectra were conducted by employing a confocal Raman spectrometer (America, iHR-550) with a 532 nm laser. The metal Ni loading of all samples were conducted using NexION 350X inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). 1H Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) measurement was applied to detect the liquid product, and a solvent presaturation method was employed to suppress the water peak. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterizations of the quasi-molecular catalysts As illustrated in Scheme 1 , the Ni@NC-T quasi-molecular catalyst was fabricated via a very simple post-metallization strategy using the NC-T (T represents the heat-treatment temperature) as a controlled scaffold. Firstly, Zn-DAP@MgO solid composites were prepared via self-assembly of Zn salt, DAP, and MgO template given that Zn ions can easily interact with DAP molecules to form coordination polymers [34]. Secondly, the obtained composites were thermally treated at different temperatures (T = 900 ∼ 1100 °C) for 2 h under flowing Ar, and then etched in diluted HCl solutions to remove both the MgO template and unstable Zn-containing species. Thirdly, the resulting layered NC support with large surface areas was metallized with non-noble metal salts (M = Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn) in DMF solutions under reflux, giving rise to M@NC-T catalysts, which were directly used for CO2RR without any subsequent heat treatment. The microstructure and morphologies of the Ni@NC-T catalysts (T = 900 ∼ 1100 °C) were examined using transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and atomic force microscopy (AFM). Obviously, these catalysts possess a wrinkled and lamellar structure similar to that of two-dimensional graphene materials (Fig. 1 a, Figures S1 and S2). As shown in Figure S3, the AFM results proved that the sheet thickness of Ni@NC-1100 catalyst is approximately 4.2 nm, which is equivalent to 12 ∼ 13 carbon layers [35,36]. The spherical aberration corrected high-angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) clearly indicated abundant bright spots on the surface of Ni@NC-1100, demonstrating that the isolated Ni sites were successfully embedded in the NC frameworks [37]. The loading amount, 2.81 wt% of Ni single atoms in such catalyst, was determined by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) (Figure S4). Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) images displayed the homogeneous distribution of C, N, O and Ni elements in Ni@NC-1100 sample. XRD patterns of M@NC-1100 (M = Fe, Co, Ni, Cu and Zn) and Ni@NC-T (T = 900, 1000 and 1100 °C) catalysts showed a broad diffraction peak at 24.9°, assigned to the fingerprint (002) facet of graphitic carbon. Meanwhile, another two weak diffraction peaks were found at 9.6° and 14.8°, which are due to the formation of crystalline carbon under high temperature pyrolysis of Zn-DAP complex. By comparing the standard PDF cards, it can be concluded that these two peaks correspond to the C (100) and C (110) crystal planes, respectively. No diffraction peaks of crystalline Ni NPs or NiO species were observed, indicating that these Ni ions are trapped and stabilized by surrounding N atoms.[38,39] Raman spectra of M@NC-1100 catalysts displayed two characteristic peaks at 1356 cm−1 and 1587 cm−1, which are attributed to disordered sp3 carbon (D band) and graphitic sp2 carbon (G band), respectively [40]. The specific surface area of as-prepared M@NC-1100 catalysts based on Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) analysis was in the range of 807.6 m2∙g−1 and 895.0 m2∙g−1 with an average pore diameter of 3.51 nm (Table S1). It is worth noting that such high specific surface areas and mesoporous structure are conducive to the high exposure of metal active sites and the diffusion of reactant molecules. The valence state and coordination environments of single Ni sites in Ni@NC-1000 and Ni@NC-1100 catalysts were determined by X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS). The Ni K-edge X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectra showed that the near-edge absorption energy of Ni@NC-900, Ni@NC-1000 and Ni@NC-1100 was significantly higher than that of Ni foil and slightly shifted to the right compared with NiO reference, which is consistent with the valence state of Ni between +2 and +3 observed by XPS. From the Fourier transform (FT) k 3-weighted χ(k)-function of the extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS), one main peak and a subdominant peak located at 1.56 Å and 2.72 Å, respectively, were observed, which are attributed to the respective Ni-N and Ni-C scattering path [41]. Compared with Ni foil, the Ni-Ni scattering path at ∼2.2 Å was not detected in both catalysts, demonstrating the atomically dispersed feature of Ni species [42]. The wavelet transform (WT) contour plot of Ni@NC-1100 catalyst exhibited an intensity maximum at 5.5 Å−1 in the k space, corresponding to the Ni-N coordination with respect to the Ni foil and NiO reference (Fig. 2 d-f). To identify the structural parameters and chemical configuration of Ni atoms, quantitative EXAFS fitting analysis was conducted. The fitting results revealed that the coordination number of Ni is 4.8, 5.0 and 4.9 for the first shell together with the Ni-N bond length of 2.04 Å, proving that the Ni atoms are atomically dispersed with Ni-N5 configuration in Ni@NC-T catalysts (T = 900, 1000 and 1100 °C) (Table S2) [43]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed to determine the chemical composition and electronic state of Ni@NC-T samples (Fig. 3 and Figure S5). The high-resolution N 1 s spectra of Ni@NC-T catalysts can be deconvoluted into five types of N species, corresponding to pyridinic-N (∼398.5 eV), Ni-N (∼399.3 eV), pyrrolic-N (∼400.3 eV), graphitic-N (400.7 eV) and oxidized N (403.7 eV), respectively.[14,44] It can be seen from the spectra fitting results in Fig. 3a that these catalysts contained not only 21.9 % ∼ 25.7 % Ni-N as the catalytic active site, but also 43.4 % ∼ 52 % pyridinic-N and pyrrolic-N, which can serve as Lewis basic sites to promote the enrichment of CO2 molecules on the surface of NC support (Table S3) [45,46]. The high-resolution Ni 2p spectra showed that no signal of metallic Ni was detected in the Ni@NC-T catalyst. The Ni 2p spectra exhibited two main peaks assigned to Ni 2p3/2 (∼855.7 eV) and Ni 2p1/2 (873.5 eV) along with their associated satellite features, which are consistent with the characteristics of Ni2+, while the higher binding energies at Ni 2p3/2 (∼856.9 eV) and Ni 2p1/2 (875.1 eV) correspond to those of Ni3+.[47,48] The Ni2+/Ni3+ ratio calculated from the deconvolution of the spectra indicates that the relative content of Ni2+ ranges from 57.4 % to 64.4 %, while the content of Ni3+ fluctuates between 35.6 % and 42.6 % (Table S4). The fitting results of Ni 2p spectra are consistent with the XAS analysis, both of which suggest that Ni is in the ionic state of Niδ+ (2 < δ < 3), which is obviously different from the low valent Ni-N-C catalysts prepared by traditional pyrolysis method.[49,50]. 3.2 Electrocatalytic performance of CO2RR The electrocatalytic CO2 reduction performance of the Ni@NC-T and M@NC-1100 catalysts was first investigated by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) in CO2-saturated 0.5 M KHCO3 solution at applied potentials ranging from −0.4 to −1.4 V with an interval of 0.1 V. All potentials here refer to reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). The LSV of Ni@NC-1100 showed an obviously larger response current and a positive shift in onset potential in CO2-saturated KHCO3 solution than in Ar-saturated solution, manifesting its catalytic activity for CO2RR (Figure S6a). As revealed in Fig. 4 a, the Ni@NC-1100 catalyst exhibited the highest cathodic current density at potentials more negative than −0.42 V vs. RHE, reaching up to 12 mA·cm−2 with 98.2 % FECO at −1.02 V, which is far beyond that of other control catalysts. The FECO at different potentials was compared to evaluate the reaction selectivity of the prepared catalysts (Fig. 4b and Figure S7). It was found that the FECO and partial current density of CO (jCO) follow the order: Ni@NC-1100 > Ni@NC-1000 > Ni@NC-900 > Co@NC-1100 > Fe@NC-1100 > Zn@NC-1100 > Cu@NC-1100. It can be reasonably believed that the selection of appropriate transition metal salts plays a crucial role in the performance of CO2RR for the specified support. Notably, the optimized Ni@NC-1100 catalyst exhibited a maximum FECO of 99.1 % at −0.72 V vs. RHE with the CO current density of 11.4 mA·cm−2 as well as the FECO > 96 % over a wide range of applied voltages (−0.52 V to −1.12 V vs. RHE). In addition, no liquid products were detected in the aqueous phase after electrolysis by 1H NMR analysis, confirming its excellent CO selectivity (Figure S6). Such an excellent FECO of Ni@NC-1100 with Ni-N5 moieties was higher than that of the most state-of-the art electrocatalysts over a wide range of potentials in H-type cells (Table S5). To facilitate the comparison of the intrinsic activity of the prepared catalysts, the TOF value of CO2-to-CO conversion were calculated assuming that all transition metal atoms are accessible and equally active (Fig. 4e). The TOF value of Ni@NC-1100 was up to 9693 h−1 with 98.2 % FECO at −1.02 V vs. RHE, which was approximately 2.4 and 4.5 times higher than that of Co@NC-1100 with 77.1 % FECO and Fe@NC-1100 with 74.9 % FECO. Figure S8a showed that Ni@NC-1100 catalyst had the highest reactivity. According to linear fitting result, the Tafel slope of Ni@NC-1100 was 150.2 mV/dec, which was distinctly lower than Co@NC-1100 (201.1 mV/dec) and Fe@NC-1100 (225.8 mV/dec) catalysts. The order of Faradaic impedance was Ni@NC-1100 < Co@NC-1100 < Fe@NC-1100, indicating that the charge transfer rate of Ni@NC-1100 catalyst was the fastest during the reaction (Figure S8b), which was consistent with the electrocatalytic performance of CO2RR. These results verified that the excellent CO2RR performance mainly originates from the high accessibility and dense surface of Ni-N5 sites. The electrochemical stability is an important criterion to evaluate the catalyst performance in CO2RR. The long-term stability of the Ni@NC-1100 catalyst was tested at optimal potential for FECO, which displayed a FECO of >98 % and maintained a satisfactory stability during the 24 h continuous electrolysis. 3.3 CO2RR performance in flow cell with GDEs Electrocatalysts operating at high current densities (>200 mA/cm2) are essential to achieve the industrial production of CO2RR. Based on the above H-cell tests, the catalytic performance of Ni@NC-900, Ni@NC-1000 and Ni@NC-1100 catalysts was further evaluated in a flow cell system (Fig. 5 a). The gas diffusion electrode (GDEs) were prepared by airbrushing different catalyst inks onto hydrophobic carbon paper. Based on the analysis of LSV, I-t curves and gaseous products, it was found that the Ni@NC-1100 electrocatalyst showed the best performance with an earlier onset potential of −0.15 V vs. RHE for CO2RR than other catalysts (−0.17 V vs. RHE) in a 1.0 M KOH electrolyte. Fig. 5c displayed the potential-dependent FECO on all catalysts in the range from −0.17 to −1.17 V vs. RHE. The FECO for Ni@NC-1000 and Ni@NC-1100 were nearly 100 % at the potential range of −0.37 to −1.17 V, the higher partial current density of Ni@NC-1100 indicated the higher catalytic activity. In Fig. 5d, the Ni@NC-1100 catalyst exhibited highest jCO over the entire potential range studied, which achieved a maximum jCO of −343.8 mA/cm2 at −0.97 V vs. RHE, which is obviously better than that of Ni@NC-1000 (−224.5 mA/cm2) and Ni@NC-900 (−61.5 mA/cm2) catalysts. The TOF value of Ni@NC-1100 was up to 37.2 s−1 at −0.97 V vs. RHE, which was approximately 2.1 and 32.9 times higher than that of Ni@NC-1000 and Ni@NC-900 (Fig. 5e). The electrochemical stability is an important criterion to evaluate the catalyst performance in CO2RR. The long-term stability of the Ni@NC-1100 catalyst was tested at −200 mA/cm2 for FECO, which displayed a FECO of >99.5 % and maintained a satisfactory stability during the 10 h continuous electrolysis. The catalytic performance of Ni@NC-1100 catalyst was particularly impressive in a wide potential range and high current density compared with the state-of-the-art Ni-based catalysts for converting CO2 to CO product. 3.4 Mechanistic understanding of CO2RR on Ni-N5 sites In order to further understand the mechanism of electrocatalytic CO2 reduction to CO for Ni@NC-1100 catalysts, DFT calculations based on a computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) model were conducted [51]. The in-plane NiN4 site coordinated with axial pyrrole, pyridine and aniline nitrogen embedded in N-doped lamellar graphene models were built based on the XPS and EXAFS results. Generally, the mechanism for CO2RR-to-CO involves the first proton-coupled electron transfer to form *COOH intermediate and subsequently the second proton-coupled electron transfer to generate *CO intermediate, followed by the desorption of *CO intermediate [52], and the elemental reaction steps are shown below: (1) CO 2 ( g ) + * + H + ( aq ) + e - ⟷ ∗ COOH (2) ∗ COOH + H + ( aq ) + e - ⟷ *CO + H 2 O (l) (3) *CO ⟷ CO (g) + * where * represents the active site on substrate. As shown in Fig. 6 a and 6b, the calculated free energy diagrams of CO2RR to CO on Ni@NC-1100 catalyst at 0 V and −0.82 V vs. RHE displayed that the first protonation of CO2 to form *COOH is the potential-determining step (PDS) for both NiN4 sites with either axial pyrrole or aniline coordination. The initial optimization results of the Ni-N5 model showed that the axial distance between the pyridine group in the NC scaffold and NiN4 was too far to form an effective coordination mode, thus it was excluded (Figure S9). The energy barrier of *COOH formation process on NiN4 with an axial pyrrole coordination (ΔG = 0.655 eV) was lower than that on NiN4 with an axial aniline coordination (ΔG = 0.827 eV) in Ni@NC-1100, further reflecting that the highly coordinated Ni-N5 site is composed of NiN4 with an axial pyrrolic-N. Moreover, the reaction energy barrier of PDS rapidly decreased from 1.475 eV to 0.655 eV when the applied voltage increased from 0 V to −0.82 V, indicating a significant acceleration of the catalytic process. To explore the reaction mechanism of CO formation, the Tafel slope at Ni@NC-1100 electrode was determined to be 150.2 mV dec−1 much lower than those of Co@NC-1100 (201.1 mV dec−1) and Fe@NC-1100 (225.8 mV dec−1), suggesting the favorable reaction kinetics for the first electron transfer of adsorbed CO2 (Figure S8) [53,54]. Altogether, DFT calculations proved that the NiN4 with axial pyrrolic-N group in Ni@NC-1100 catalyst serves as the intrinsic active site for CO2RR to CO. Based on the above analysis, the reaction pathways of CO2RR to CO over Ni sites are proposed in NiN4 with axial coordinated pyrrolic-N structure from Ni@NC-1100 (Fig. 6c). 4 Conclusion In conclusion, a novel Ni@NC-T quasi-molecular catalyst with highly accessible and abundant Ni-N5 sites has been successfully prepared by a simple post-metallization strategy using nitrogen-doped carbon with ultra-high specific surface area as a scaffold. The as-prepared Ni@NC-1100 catalyst exhibited 99 % FEco at −0.72 V vs. RHE and FEco above 96 % over a wide potential window (−0.52 V ∼ − 1.12 V), which was superior to those of pyrolized Ni-N-C-based electrocatalysts. The outstanding performance for CO2-to-CO conversion can be ascribed to the highly efficient Ni-N5 active sites anchored on NC support with an additional axial ligand coordinated to NiN4. DFT calculations suggested that the presence of axial pyrrolic-N ligand significantly enhanced the Ni-N5 active sites for CO2 activation, with it displaying the lowest activation energy for forming the *COOH intermediate compared to other axial ligands. Such a quasi-molecular catalyst with a high coordination Ni-N5 structure has superior catalytic performance compared to other supported NiPc MDEs and its related COFs and MOFs, as well as Ni-N-C catalysts prepared by high-temperature pyrolysis. Therefore, the concept presented in this work can guide the exploration of highly efficient quasi-molecular catalysts for many other energy and fine chemical conversion reactions. coredata.dc:description: Electrochemical production of high value-added CO from CO2 on transition metal-nitrogen-carbon (M−N−C) catalysts is a promising approach to achieve carbon neutral economy, yet the quest for robust catalysts is driven by achieving > 96 % CO faradaic efficiency (FE) under low overpotential and wide potential range. Herein, we report a novel synthetic approach involving post-metallization of the pre-synthesized N-doped carbon (NC-T) support for the fabrication of robust and efficient Ni@NC-T quasi-molecular catalysts toward CO2 electroreduction reaction (CO2RR). The optimum Ni@NC-1100 catalyst exhibited an extremely high FECO > 99 % at −0.72 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). Of interest is the FECO maintained above 96 % over a wide potential window from −0.52 V to −1.12 V. Density functional theory (DFT) calculation validated that the presence of axial pyrrolic-N significantly enhances the Ni-N5 active site for CO2 activation, resulting in the lowest activation energy for the *COOH intermediate generation compared to other axial ligands.
coredata.dc:title: Highly coordinated Ni-N5 sites for efficient electrocatalytic CO2 reduction toward CO with faradaic efficiency exceeding 99%
